node.title: Anti-coup protesters in Sudan met with deadly gunfire
node.description: At least 3 protesters were killed as thousands took to the streets to demand a return to civilian rule, and the generals in charge responded with force.
node.content: ["Cairo \u2014 Sudanese security forces opened fire on protesters Monday, killing at least three people and wounding several as thousands took to the streets in Khartoum and elsewhere in the country to denounce an October military coup, activists said. The military takeover has scuttled hopes of a peaceful transition to democracy in Sudan, more than two years after a popular uprising forced the removal of longtime autocrat Omar al-Bashir in April 2019. \u00a0 The turmoil has been amplified after Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok stepped down earlier this month. Hamdok resigned after his efforts to bridge the gap between the generals and the country's pro-democracy movement failed. \u00a0 Monday's deaths bring to at least 67 the number of people killed in near-daily demonstrations in the capital of Khartoum and other cities and towns in Sudan. Footage circulating online shows protesters, mostly young people, marching in the streets of Khartoum and its twin city of Omdurman. There were also protests in Port Sudan, Wad Madani Obaid and the western Darfur region.", "Activist Nazim Sirag said three protesters were killed when security forces opened fire to break up a march in Khartoum. He said several others were wounded by gunshots. \u00a0 The Sudan Doctors Committee, which is part of the pro-democracy movement, also reported the deaths and said dozens of others were wounded Monday in Khartoum. \u00a0 The fatalities will likely further complicate U.N. efforts to find a way out of the ongoing crisis. The United Nations and Western governments have widely condemned the crackdown on protesters.", "The demonstrations are called by the Sudanese Professionals Association and the Resistance Committees, which were the backbone of the uprising against al-Bashir. The two groups reject negotiations with the military, insisting it hand over power to a fully civilian government to lead the transition. \u00a0 The generals, meanwhile, reject the protesters' demands, saying that power will be handed over only to an elected government.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
